[[Harvard Business School]] | occupation = Former [[CEO]] of [[Synthes]]
[[Chairman]] of The Wyss Foundation and The HJW Foundation | networth = [[United States dollar|$]]5.6 billion
(May 2017){{cite web|title=Hansjoerg Wyss|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/hansjoerg-wyss|website=Forbes|accessdate=19 May 2017}} | children = [[Amy Wyss]] }} '''Hansjörg Wyss''' (born 19 September 1935) is a Swiss entrepreneur, businessman, and philanthropist. He is the founder and was president, then chairman, of Synthes USA, until its sale in 2012. Wyss lives in Wyoming and has supported philanthropic causes relating to environmental protection, social justice, and science. His contributions led to the establishment of the [[Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering]] at [[Harvard University]] in 2009 and he created the Wyss Foundation, which aims to conserve natural environments, including public lands in the [[Western United States]], [[Africa]], and [[South America]]. As of 2017, Wyss has a net worth of US$5.6 billion, according to ''[[Forbes]]''.Wilkinson, Tara Loader. [http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2008-10-08/switzerlands-second-richest-man-makes-big-donation-to-harvard Switzerland's second richest man makes big donation to Harvard], ''[[Financial News|Wealth Bulletin]]'', 8 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. ==Early life and career== Wyss was born in [[Bern]], Switzerland in 1935. His father sold mechanical calculators and his mother was a homemaker. He was raised in an apartment with two sisters. After receiving a master's degree in Civil and Structural Engineering from the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich]] in 1959,{{cite news|title=Wyss May Top Bertarelli as Richest Swiss Man in Synthes Sale|author=Allison Connolly |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-04-19/wyss-may-replace-bertarelli-as-richest-swiss-man-in-synthes-sale|work=Bloomberg.com|date=20 April 2011|accessdate=26 June 2015}} Wyss earned an [[MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School]] in 1965. Following that, he worked in various positions in the textile industry, including plant engineer and project manager for [[Chrysler]] in Pakistan, Turkey, and the Philippines.{{cite web|url=https://www.alumni.hbs.edu/stories/Pages/story-bulletin.aspx?num=2000|title=Hansjörg Wyss, MBA 1965|date=1 January 2007|work=alumni.hbs.edu|publisher=[[Harvard Business School]]|accessdate=25 June 2015}} Wyss also worked in the steel industry in [[City of Brussels|Brussels, Belgium]]. During his time working in that industry, Wyss ran a side business selling airplanes. Through one sale, he met a surgeon who had co-founded Swiss [[medical device]] manufacturer [[Synthes]].{{cite news|title=Legal troubles for local billionaire|author=Miriam Hill|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20091206_Legal_troubles_for_local_billionaire.html|work=[[Philadelphia Media Network|Philly.com]]|date=6 December 2009|accessdate=9 July 2015}} After that meeting, Wyss spent two years learning about the medical device industry. He founded and became president of Synthes USA in 1977. ==Synthes USA== {{main|Synthes}} In 1977, Wyss founded and became president of Synthes USA, the U.S. division of Switzerland-based [[Synthes]] medical device manufacturer making internal screws and plates for broken bones. In an early initiative, Wyss opened a Synthes USA manufacturing plant in Colorado. Prior to that, another Switzerland company manufactured Synthes' devices and exported them to the U.S. Under Wyss' control, the U.S. division expanded its sales team and trained surgeons how to use its products. Wyss served as Synthes' worldwide CEO and chairman until his resignation as CEO in 2007. He maintained his post as company chairman until [[Johnson & Johnson]] acquired Synthes in 2012.{{cite news|title=Synthes Sale Creates $8.7 Billion Man|author=Matthew Herper|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/matthewherper/2011/04/27/synthes-sale-creates-8-7-billion-man|work=[[Forbes]]|date=27 April 2011|accessdate=13 October 2015}}{{cite news|title=Johnson & Johnson completes $20B takeover of Synthes|author=John George|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/news/2012/06/14/johnson-johnson-completes-20b.html|newspaper=[[American City Business Journals|Philadelphia Business Journal]]|date=14 June 2012|accessdate=21 July 2015}} During his tenure, Wyss said discussions of new products made up one-third of board meetings. A manager assigned to the Norian project testified before a grand jury that "for somebody who is at his level and his level of success, I would say he [Wyss] has a surprising amount of contact with what's going on." Staff recalled meetings in which he intensively probed their projects. In 2009, top executives at Synthes were indicted by U.S. Attorneys for Eastern Pennsylvania for using an untested calcium-phosphate-based bone cement on human patients without the authorization from the [[Food and Drug Administration]], which resulted in the deaths of three people.[http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/three-people-died-in-illegal-human-experiments-carried-out-by-john-podesta-backers-firm/article/2551139 "Three people died in illegal human experiments carried out by John Podesta backer's firm"], washingtonexaminer.com; accessed 21 October 2015. Wyss was not indicted but four of Synthes' top executives were convicted and sentenced to prison terms.[http://fortune.com/2012/09/18/bad-to-the-bone-a-medical-horror-story "Bad to the Bone - a Medical Horror Story"], fortune.com, 18 September 2012. In 2012 Wyss sold the company for $21.3 billion in cash and stock to [[Johnson & Johnson]].Wilkinson, Tara Loader. [http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2008-10-08/switzerlands-second-richest-man-makes-big-donation-to-harvard Switzerland's second richest man makes big donation to Harvard], ''[[Financial News|Wealth Bulletin]]'', 8 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. ==Philanthropy== According to ''[[Forbes]]'', Wyss is "among the most [[philanthropy|philanthropic]] people in the world". Between 2004 and 2008, ''[[Businessweek]]'' estimated that Wyss personally donated nearly USD$277 million. His giving has increased since the sale of Synthes in 2012 and in 2013 he signed [[The Giving Pledge]], agreeing to give away the majority of his fortune.{{cite news|title=Wyss, Yet Another Big Philanthropist, Turns to the Oceans|author=Tate Williams|url=http://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2014/11/4/wyss-yet-another-big-philanthropist-turns-to-the-oceans.html|work=Inside Philanthropy|date=4 November 2014|accessdate=9 July 2015}} The assets of his charitable foundations equal nearly $2 billion. His primary philanthropic causes are the [[Environmental movement|environment]], [[social justice]], and [[science]], but he frequently contributes to historic projects and [[Europe]]an museums. The Wyss Foundation, a charitable organization he founded, has awarded grants for environmental protection as well as to [[Progressivism|progressive]] policy organizations, including the [[Center for Budget and Policy Priorities]], [[Health Leads]], and the [[Constitutional Accountability Center]]. ===Environmental protection=== As of 2017, Wyss and the Wyss Foundation have donated more than $350 million to [[environmental protection]], including [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation]] of national forests and other public lands in the [[Western United States]].{{cite news|title='Quietly philanthropic' tycoon makes his mark in the West|author=Phil Taylor|url=http://www.eenews.net/stories/1060015651|work=[[Environment & Energy Publishing]]|date=24 May 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} In October 2018 Wyss published an article in the [[New York Times]] stating that he was contributing 1 billion dollars to environmental causes.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/31/opinion/earth-biodiversity-conservation-billion-dollars.html|title=We Have to Save the Planet. So I’m Donating $1 Billion.|publisher=''New York Times''|accessdate=2 November 2018}} Wyss has stated that he became passionate about the American West and land preservation after visiting the U.S. in 1958 as a student and taking a summer job as a [[Surveying|surveyor]] with the Colorado Highway Department.{{cite news|title=Bernese billionaire works to keep West wild|author=Marie-Christine Bonzom|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/bernese-billionaire-works-to-keep-west-wild/31446480|work=[[Swissinfo]]|date=27 October 2011|accessdate=9 July 2015}} In 1998, he created the Wyss Foundation{{cite news|title=Another Billionaire Comes to the Defense of Africa's Elephants and Rhinos|author=Paul M.J. Suchecki|url=http://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2015/3/18/another-billionaire-comes-to-the-defense-of-africas-elephant.html|work=Inside Philanthropy|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} to establish and sponsor informal partnerships between non-governmental organizations and the United States government to place large swathes of land under permanent protection in the American West. By 2006, via the initial efforts of the foundation, almost {{convert|4400000|acre|km2}} of public land had been labeled as [[National Monument (United States)|national monuments]] and [[National Conservation Area|national conservation areas]].{{cite news|title=Hansjörg Wyss honored for his philanthropy|author=Jim Gerry|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:qH8gSvF3dG0J:https://www.aofoundation.org/Documents/aodialogue3_06.pdf+&cd=6&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us|work=[[AO Foundation]] |date=2006|accessdate=9 July 2015}} The organization also sponsors The Wyss Scholars Program for [[Postgraduate education|graduate-level education]] in conservation.{{cite news|title=Island student wins scholarship|url=http://www.bainbridgereview.com/community/295491161.html#|work=[[The Review (Bainbridge Island)|Bainbridge Review]]|date=7 March 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} The Wyss Foundation's landscape protection strategies have included assisting the purchase of mineral leases from oil and gas companies.{{cite news|title=Save the planet? Buy it|author=Jonathan Franklin|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/earthnews/3349689/Save-the-planet-Buy-it.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=16 August 2008|accessdate=9 July 2015}}{{cite news|title=Trout Unlimited buys Rocky Mountain Front petroleum leases|author=Associated Press|url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/trout-unlimited-buys-rocky-mountain-front-petroleum-leases/article_4c3a694c-dcdc-547f-94fe-1cb9dafabcd4.html|work=[[Billings Gazette]]|date=12 April 2007|accessdate=17 September 2015}} Other causes the Wyss Foundation supports includes river restorations, [[Marine conservation|ocean conservation]] in Peru and Canada, anti-[[poaching]] efforts in Africa, and [[environmental journalism]].{{cite news|title=Behind one of the Nature Conservancy's largest ever forest purchases|author=Marc Gunther|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2015/jan/30/behind-one-of-the-nature-conservancys-largest-ever-forest-purchases|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 January 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} In 2017, the organization announced a charitable commitment of $65 million to African Parks, a conservation NGO overseeing ten parks in seven African nations, to help create new protected areas in Africa.{{cite news |title=With Africa's Wilds Facing Growing Threats, A Billionaire Steps Up |author=Tate Williams |url=https://www.insidephilanthropy.com/home/2017/3/1/another-large-sum-from-wyss-for-land-protection-this-time-in-africa |work=[[Inside Philanthropy]] |date=1 March 2017 |accessdate=7 April 2017}} In 2010, Wyss personally gave The Nature Conservancy $35 million to purchase 310,000 acres in Montana as part of one of the largest private conservation purchases in the United States.{{cite news|title=Hansjorg Wyss: Swiss Billionaire Puts $35 Million Toward Conservation In Western Montana|author=Matthew Brown|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/14/hansjorg-wyss-swiss-billi_n_796759.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=14 December 2010|accessdate=9 July 2015}} He donated $4.25 million to [[The Trust for Public Land]] in 2013 for the purchase of oil and gas leases in [[Wyoming]] to prevent development in the Hoback Basin. In 2016, Wyss made another donation to the Trust for Public Land that resulted in the expansion of [[Saguaro National Park]] in Arizona by 300 acres, including a mile and a half of Rincon Creek.{{cite news |title=44 acres added to Saguaro National Park east |author=Elizabeth Walton |url=http://www.tucsonnewsnow.com/story/34977311/44-acres-added-to-saguaro-national-park-east |work=[[KMSB|TucsonNewsNow]] |date=23 March 2017 |accessdate=7 April 2017}} Wyss is involved with [[The Wilderness Society (United States)|The Wilderness Society]], [[Rails-to-Trails Conservancy|Rails-to-Trails]], and serves on the boards of the [[Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance]], [[Center for American Progress]], and the Grand Canyon Trust.{{cite news|title=HBS Receives $25 Million Gift for Doctoral Program|url=http://www.harbus.org/2004/hbs-receives-25-million-2892|work=The Harbus|date=25 October 2004|accessdate=25 June 2015}} In 2011, Wyss won the [[Bob Marshall (wilderness activist)|Robert Marshall Award]] from The Wilderness Society for his conservation work. In January 2015, [[Conservatism in the United States|a conservative]] U.S. news site ''[[The Daily Caller]]'' accused [[John Podesta]], who was at the time an advisor on environmental issues to the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]], of an ethics violation for pushing the advocacy agenda of a former employer, because he had previously received $87,000 as a consulting fee for work he did for Wyss' HJW Foundation in 2013 (that organization was later merged with the Wyss Foundation). It was noted that the Wyss Foundation had previously donated $4 million to the [[Center for American Progress]] (CAP), which Podesta founded.{{cite news|title=Obama adviser Podesta caught green-handed in major ethics violation|author=Richard Pollock|url=http://dailycaller.com/2015/01/29/obama-adviser-podesta-caught-green-handed-in-major-ethics-violation|work=[[The Daily Caller]]|date=29 January 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} According to the ''[[High Country News]]'', "nothing ever came of the accusations".{{cite web|title=John Podesta: Legacy maker|author=Elizabeth Shogren|url=https://www.hcn.org/issues/47.9/john-podesta-legacy-maker|work=[[High Country News]]|date=25 May 2015|accessdate=25 June 2015}} ===Support of scientific research=== In 2007, he received the Harvard Business School Alumni Achievement Award,{{cite web|url=https://www.alumni.hbs.edu/stories/Pages/story-bulletin.aspx?num=2000|title=Hansjörg Wyss, MBA 1965|date=1 January 2007|work=alumni.hbs.edu|publisher=[[Harvard Business School]]|accessdate=25 June 2015}}[http://business.inquirer.net/money/features/view/20070930-91654/Zobel_gets_highest_alumni_award_from_Harvard Zobel gets highest alumni award from Harvard] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705210842/http://business.inquirer.net/money/features/view/20070930-91654/Zobel_gets_highest_alumni_award_from_Harvard |date=5 July 2015 }}, ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''; retrieved 15 October 2008. and in fall 2008, it was announced that Wyss donated the largest single endowment from one source in Harvard's history when he gave $125 million to found a multidisciplinary institute, the [[Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering]] at [[Harvard University]].[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27073959 "Alum gives Harvard $125 million"], msnbc.com; retrieved 15 October 2008.[https://www.usatoday.com/news/education/2008-10-07-harvard-donation_N.htm Harvard alum donates record $125M], usatoday.com, 7 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. In 2012-13, he announced the creation of the [[Campus Biotech]] and of its [[Wyss Center for Bio- and Neuro-engineering]] in [[Geneva]], Switzerland. In 2014, Wyss donated $120 million to the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich]] and the [[University of Zurich]] for the new Wyss Translational Center Zurich.{{cite news|title=Hansjörg Wyss sponsoring research|author=André Müller|url=http://www.nzz.ch/zuerich/120-millionen-dollar-fuer-zuercher-forschung-1.18443332|work=[[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]]|date=12 December 2014|accessdate=26 June 2015}} ==Political views== In 2015, Wyss publicly declared himself to be in favour of higher inheritance taxes (estate/death duty taxes) for the wealthy in [[Switzerland]].{{cite web|title=Blick: Hansjörg Wyss, der Freund der Erbschaftssteuer|url=http://www.blick.ch/news/politik/hansjoerg-wyss-der-freund-der-erbschaftssteuer-keiner-weiss-wo-er-steuern-zahlt-id3825709.html}} There has been a long-lasting rivalry between billionaire Wyss, who supports left-wing politics, and billionaire conservative [[Christoph Blocher]]. Both entered into public debates about the bilateral contracts between [[Switzerland]] and the [[European Union]] as well as the limitation of immigrants into Switzerland. Wyss, on the one hand, attempted to outline and foster the advantages of openness towards the EU and immigrants while Blocher, on the other hand, sought to highlight and emphasize the independence of Switzerland in those matters.{{cite web|title=Blick: Hansjörg Wyss und Christoph Blocher - Die Schlacht der alten Milliardäre|url=http://www.blick.ch/news/politik/wahlen2015/hansjoerg-wyss-und-christoph-blocher-die-schlacht-der-alten-milliardaere-id4095937.html}} ==Personal life== Wyss is an active hiker, skier and backpacker. He is also a hobby pilot. He lives in Wyoming,{{cite news|title=#240 Hansjoerg Wyss|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/hansjoerg-wyss|work=[[Forbes]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=6 August 2015}} where he is involved in outdoor education programs and funds local efforts to conserve wildlife habitat and public lands in the Rocky Mountains.{{cite news|title=Wilderness Medicine Campus Coming to Wyoming|author=Jeanne O'Brien|url=http://www.snewsnet.com/press-release/wilderness-medicine-campus-coming-to-wyoming|work=snewsnet.com|date=5 January 2011|accessdate=18 August 2015}} In 2000, Wyss purchased the {{convert|900|acre|km2|adj=on}} Halter Ranch & Vineyard in western [[Paso Robles, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/halter-596457-strupp-ranch.html|title=Swiss billionaire merges winemaking, conservation on coast|author=Faith Echtermeyer|date=8 January 2014|work=ocregister.com|publisher=[[Orange County Register]]|accessdate=25 June 2015}} The ranch includes an 1,800 acre wildlife preserve and a 281-acre vineyard producing 13 [[varietal]]s using methods that are "Sustainability in Practice" certified. The ranch hosts tours and was named "Best Vineyard Experience" by ''[[Sunset (magazine)|Sunset Magazine]]'' in 2015.{{cite news |title=At Paso Robles' Halter Ranch winery, nature and science meet |author=Sally Buffalo |url=http://www.sanluisobispo.com/living/food-drink/wine-beer/article102362507.html |work=[[The Tribune (San Luis Obispo)]] |date=16 September 2016 |accessdate=7 April 2017}} As of 2017, Wyss ranks 281 on the ''[[Forbes]]'' list of billionaires, with an estimated net worth of approximately [[United States dollar|$]]5.5 billion.{{cite web|title=Hansjoerg Wyss|url=https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/#version:static_search:wyss|website=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=2 January 2015}}Wilkinson, Tara Loader. [http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2008-10-08/switzerlands-second-richest-man-makes-big-donation-to-harvard Switzerland's second richest man makes big donation to Harvard], ''[[Financial News|Wealth Bulletin]]'', 8 October 2008; retrieved 15 October 2008. He ranks number 235 on the ''[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]'' list of billionaires.{{cite news|title=Bloomberg Billionaires Index|author=|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/|work=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg Business]]|date=7 April 2017|accessdate=7 April 2017}} Wyss' daughter [[Amy Wyss|Amy]] also lives in Wyoming.{{cite news|title=#1044 Amy Wyss|author=|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/amy-wyss/|work=[[Forbes]]|date=18 August 2015|accessdate=18 August 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110511194555/http://www.halterranch.com/Our-Story/bios/hansjorg_wyss Halter Ranch website], halterranch.com *[http://wyss.harvard.edu Wyss Institute for Biologically Inspired Engineering], wyss.harvard.edu *[http://wyssfoundation.org/ The Wyss Foundation], wyssfoundation.org {{Portal bar|Biography|Switzerland}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wyss, Hansjorg}} [[Category:ETH Zurich alumni]] [[Category:Giving Pledgers]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bern]] [[Category:Swiss billionaires]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:Swiss philanthropists]] [[Category:Swiss emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:People from Wilson, Wyoming]]
