[[International Colour Association]] }} An international colour day (ICD) has been considered as appropriate since [[colour]] is, thanks to [[visual perception]], one of the most influential phenomena in people’s lives and also one of the channels that contributes most greatly to the perception of reality. All around the world memorable colour activities are increasingly being developed during the International Colour Day. ==Background== The adoption of an international day of colour was proposed in 2008 by the Portuguese Color Association, whose president, [http://www.fa.ulisboa.pt/docentes/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1398%3Amaria-joao-de-carvalho-durao-dos-santos&catid=78%3Adefault-registration&lang=pt Maria Joao Durao], presented the idea to the [[International Colour Association]]. The proposal was agreed in 2009 among the members of this society, which is composed of national associations and members representing more than 30 countries. ==Why March 21st / The Equinox== The choice of the date comprised a good deal of discussion. Among all suggestions, the idea exposed by Leonhard Oberascher (from Austria) prevailed: every year, March 21 is the “[[equinox]]” – aequus (equal) and nox (night). Around the equinox, the night and day are approximately equally long, symbolically relating to the complementary nature of [[light]] and darkness, light and shadow expressed in all human cultures. ==Logo== There was an international competition for the design of the logo, and the winner was announced at the 2012 meeting of the [[International Colour Association]], AIC 2012 held in [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]]. As expressed by designer Hosanna Yau, from Hong Kong, "two circles form an eye, with an equal half of rainbow color and black representing light and darkness, day and night, everyone feast one's eye on the international color day." ==Activities== Some of the activities and events that are unfolded on the International Colour Day: * Arts exhibitions, architectural projects, design, decoration, fashion.... * Meetings, debates, scientific events... * Workshops on the use of [[colour]] and [[light]] for both adults and children. * Contests on colour and light design. * Wearing national or regional identity colours. ==References and links== * [http://www.aic-color.org/news/ICDproposal.pdf] Proposal for the creation of the ICD * [http://www.aic-color.org] Website of the International Colour Association ==International Colour Day in ... == * [http://www.coloursociety.org.au/events/international-colour-day.aspx] Australia * [http://www.procor.org.br/evento-para-o-dia-internacional-da-cor-marco-2015/] Brazil * [http://www.asociaciondelcolor.cl/2011/03/21-de-marzo-dia-internacional-del-color/] Chile * [http://thaicolour.com/News.html] Thailand * [http://www.kleurenvisie.nl/] The Netherlands [http://www.kleurenvisie.nl/] Pakistan * [http://www.iscc.org/resources/HistoricColorScientists.php] United States * [http://www.elcolorcomunica.com/p/dia-del-color.html] About the ICD, in Spanish * [http://www.coloret.polimi.it/images/stories/ALLEGATI/colour%20day%20competition%20march%202012.pdf] ICD logo competition ==International Colour Day activities ...== * [http://www.aic-color.org/news/ICDreport2014.pdf] in the year 2014 [[Category:Color organizations]] [[Category:Color]] [[Category:March observances]]

'''Job sharing''' or '''work sharing''' is an [[employment]] arrangement where typically two people are retained on a [[part-time]] or reduced-time basis to perform a job normally fulfilled by one person working [[full-time]]. Since all positions are shared thus leads to a net reduction in per-employee income. The people sharing the job work as a team to complete the job task and are equally responsible for the job workload. [[Remuneration|Compensation]] is apportioned between the workers. Working hours, pay and holidays are divided equally. The [[Pay-as-you-earn tax|''pay as you go'']] system helps make deductions for national insurance and [[Superannuation Act 2010|superannuations]] are made as a straightforward percentage.<ref>{{cite journal |pmc=1792857|year=1991|author1=Baildam|first1=E. M.|title=Job sharing|journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood|volume=66|issue=3|pages=282–283|last2=Ewing|first2=C. I.|last3=Jones|first3=R|last4=Cummins|first4=M|pmid=2025001|doi=10.1136/adc.66.3.282}}</ref>
==History in the United States== The news media began reporting in earnest on job sharing in the 1970s and 1980s.<ref name=mckay>{{cite web|url=http://careerplanning.about.com/od/jobsharing/a/job_sharing.htm|title=Job Sharing - An Interview|accessdate=2009-08-13}}</ref> The practice was most often described as a solution tailored for women, as one Associated Press article summarized, "a compromise between fulltime housework and [[full-time]] employment".<ref name=boston_ap>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bRgHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wzUDAAAAIBAJ&dq=job-sharing&pg=7290%2C2397709|title=Rome News-Tribune - Google News Archive Search|accessdate=2009-08-13}}</ref>
===1970s=== In 1972 the New Ways to Work Foundation was funded, it is a [[non-profit organization]] founded in the San Francisco Bay area. Its main focus was to help "establish a work world that responds to the changing needs of individuals and organizations".<ref name="ReferenceA">Olmsted, Barney: And Others Job Sharing in the Public Sector. New Ways to Work, Palo Alto, Calif.; Women's Bureau Washington, D. C. Retrieved 2016</ref>
In 1978 the International Personnel Management Association and the Institute of [[Local government|Local Self Government]] joined with New Ways to Work to sponsor a conference on job sharing in the public sector. More than 80 public agencies sent representatives who were to learn about the experiences in increasing the number of job sharing projects. The Part Time Career Employment Act pl 95-437 was passed in 1978 as well. It narrowed the definition of part-time career employment from scheduled work of less than 40 hours a week to scheduled work between 16–32 hours per week.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===2000s=== Job sharing became even more prevalent during the 2000s, as women have succeeded professionally in greater numbers and proportionally seek out alternative work arrangements.<ref name="mckay" /> in the early 2000s, two important factors began to push the job sharing movement. The access to information became increasingly easy to access and the demographics in the workforce began to change. The birth of the World Wide Web made it easier for companies and job share participants to share information through web tools like email, instant messaging, web portals, online databases and multi-user domains, these web tools allowed employees to share work in a more collaborative environment and in an [[asynchrony (computer programming)|asynchronous]] manner. The ever-changing [[demographics]] in the United States also drove the job sharing arrangement. With most of the [[Baby boomers|baby boomer]] generation leaving the United States workforce and retiring, generation X and Y transitioned their lifestyles to an even better balance between family and work. Gender has also impacted the work force demographics: in 2004, women made up 59% of the workforce, with 50% of them in management professional positions.<ref name=":4">7.Crampton, Suzanne; Douglas, Ceasar; Hodge, John; and Mishra, Jitendra (2003) "Job Sharing: Challenges and Opportunities," Seidman Business Review: Vol. 9: Iss. 1, Article 11.Available at: h p://scholarworks.gvsu.edu/sbr/vol9/iss1/11</ref> The [[bank]]ing, [[insurance]], [[teacher|teaching]] and [[library]] professions are cited as more commonly using job sharing. Some companies that use job sharing include [[New York Life Insurance Company]], [[Fireman's Fund Insurance Company]], and [[Walgreens]] drugstores.<ref name="lussier">{{cite web|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/human-resources/121136-1.html|title=Should your organization use job sharing? - Labor & Employment > Working Hours & Patterns from AllBusiness.com|accessdate=2009-08-13}}</ref>
====Modern implementation in pharmacy academia==== In pharmacy academia, job-sharing has been seen as a tool to help encourage and increase female employment.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Rogers|first=Kelly C.|last2=Finks|first2=Shannon W.|date=2009-11-12|title=Job Sharing for Women Pharmacists in Academia|journal=American Journal of Pharmaceutical Education|volume=73|issue=7|pages=135|issn=0002-9459|pmc=2779650|pmid=19960092|doi=10.5688/aj7307135}}</ref> Female [[pharmacist]]s, compared to males, desire to work part-time earlier on in their careers.<ref name=":0" /> There is a shortage in the pharmacy field of women due to some employers not providing flexible enough schedules to match the desires of female employees.<ref name=":0" /> In academia a similar problem exists, only 20% of full professors were women in 2007 even though 66% of students enrolled in pharmacy schools are women.<ref name=":0" /> In order to retain and increase female employment in the educational field, the [[University of Tennessee]] College of Pharmacy implemented job-sharing in 2007 and has observed a noticeable improvement.<ref name=":0" />
==In other countries and areas== ===South Africa=== In South Africa, job sharing has been implemented into the work force. CEO of ''[http://www.kelly.co.za/job-opportunities Kelly]'', South Africa's first job recruitment agency, Kayee Vittee, believes "The more pressure exists in the workplace, the more severe the impact on quality and productivity. Subsequently, this also has a detrimental effect on employees' wellbeing in general".<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rnews.co.za/article/11555/job-sharing-the-answer-to-work-life-balance|title=Job sharing, the answer to work-life balance?|website=www.rnews.co.za|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref> ''[[Solidarity (South African trade union)|Solidarity]]'', a South African trade union that also protects and negotiates workers rights recently developed a social plan that encourages job share as an optimum alternative to full-time jobs.<ref name=":1" /> South Africa's current economy, as of April, 2016, is erratic and unemployment rate is high, so South African citizens unfortunately do not see job share as a solution though it is a beneficial resolution for the current economy.<ref name=":1" />
===Australia=== Jeremy Hayman, a senior lecturer at [[University of Auckland|Auckland University]] of Technology in [[New Zealand]] specializing in Human Resource Management and Employee Relations collected data and completed a questionnaire from office employees in a large Western Australia university.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.anzam.org/wp-content/uploads/pdf-manager/1869_HAYMANJEREMY_104.PDF|title="Flexible Work Arrangements: Exploring the Linkages between Perceived Usability of Flexible Work Schedules and Work/life Balance."|last=Hayman|first=Jeremy|date=October 28, 2016|access-date=October 28, 2016}}</ref> Though the study was limited to University employees, the primary and recognized finding is that the flexibility provided by job sharing can benefit the integration of work, family and personal life, ultimately providing a better work experience for the employee and a better work environment especially in women aged 30–39.<ref name=":6" /> Though the literature on job share in Australia is largely under represented compared to other developed countries, Hayman's research was more responsive then other preexisting Australian surveys regarding job share. The findings for this study is a great foundation for the future of job share in Australia and transforming management practice and work and social life balance.
===Europe=== The United Kingdom has implemented job sharing for a while. In many European countries, the job sharing arrangement is already a common practice in the workforce. Companies in countries like the [[Czech Republic]] and [[Poland]] have just recently supported job sharing on widespread scale without contractual restrictions.<ref name=":2" /> Other European countries like [[Slovenia]] and [[Slovakia]] have enforced legitimate job share governing.<ref name=":2" /> A European union agency, ''[[European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions|Eurofound]]'', was created by the European council in May 1975 to create better working and living environments for Europeans.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/industrial-relations-dictionary/job-sharing-0|title=Job Sharing|last=|first=|date=June 15, 2015|website=http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/|publisher=|access-date=October 28, 2016}}</ref> ''[[European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions|Eurofound]]'' meets annually to decide new policies and adapt to changing times and in 2015, ''Eurofound'' formally defined job sharing as a new form of employment.<ref name=":2" />
===Caribbean=== Caribbean countries like [[Puerto Rico]] and [[Haiti]] have also begun to practice job sharing. A few of the Caribbean islands in the Western hemisphere that have yet to adapt to the growth in the economy can possibly benefit most from job share. Many of these Caribbean countries and islands have experienced a large number of their qualified human capital who have moved towards the United States mainland, making the job supply and demand market more inconsistent and the economy more unstable.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=1&sid=ec1fcb57-ab5b-4e4a-b95c-3c43fa5ea619%40sessionmgr4010&hid=4105|title="Job-Sharing Is Worth Exploring."|last=MONCLOVA,|first=HÉCTOR|date=January 31, 2013|work=|access-date=October 28, 2016|via=EBSCOHost}}</ref> The job share program proves to be a very cost conscious from economic and business prospects.<ref name=":3" />
==Advantages and disadvantages== ===Advantages=== Employees who switch to job share from a full-time job often feel less stressed because they have more time for social and family personal activities. The millennial generation and its ever-changing demographics with more women in the work force has made accomplishing the balance of career and personal life a little harder, hence making job sharing a viable and even preferred solution.<ref name=":5" /> Job share has proven to be extremely convenient to expecting mothers, mothers and caretakers by providing them with a more flexible and less demanding job schedule and load and allowing them to take care of their dependents. Job share employees who don’t have a constant workload and do not need to constantly commute to a job on a daily basis, lowers their stress levels, resulting in healthier lives and work-life balances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hrdailyadvisor.blr.com/2013/07/30/job-sharing-the-advantages-and-disadvantages/|title=Job Sharing—The Advantages and Disadvantages|date=30 July 2013|publisher=}}</ref> For employees seeking more free time for themselves, job sharing may be a way to take back more control of their personal lives.<ref name="javitch">{{cite web|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/humanresources/employeemanagementcolumnistdavidjavitch/article170244.html#ixzz0JPCmZEYt&C|title=The Pros and Cons of Job Sharing - Entrepreneur.com|accessdate=2009-08-13}}</ref> Employees who job share frequently attribute their decision to an improvement in "[[quality of life]]".<ref name="javitch" />
For an employer, job sharing is a benefit because it keeps two valuable employers, thereby increasing intellectual capital and experience.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED504841.pdf|title=Integration Of Learning And Practice For Job Sharing Partnerships|last=Dixon-Krausse|first=Pamela Marie|date=2007|website=http://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/ED504841.pdf|publisher=ERIC|access-date=October 23, 2016}}</ref> Job sharing can also prevent future employee burnouts from high stress careers while also making the work atmosphere more enjoyable for all. Successful job share pairing creates a mutual relationship and feel accountable for one another, consequently increasing the accomplishments they achieve together. Studies have shown that net productivity increases when two people share the same 40-hour job, making for a more effective and more than likely profitable workplace for the employer.
===Disadvantages=== Job share can be conflicting if the job share participants/employees are not open to a mutual agreement to distribute everything from salary, workload and time off. Job sharing can also be a disadvantage if the employee cannot afford the part-time wages or benefits. It is also possible that job sharing can make an employee feel less adequate over time and cause less productivity over time.<ref name=":4" /> If the job share arrangement is not effective, the transition period to finding another partner could be disruptive and detrimental to the remaining employee. If proper communication and effort does not happen between the job share participants, job share can be a negative experience because the coworkers can not be held accountable to the same expectations, shifting the delicate balance of the job share arrangement.
The disadvantages for employers can start immediately if the employer is not able to successfully match two people to the job share arrangement.This can negatively effect management because of the extra effort and time could take to produce a harmonious job share arrangement.<ref name=":4" /> Though job share arrangements generally split the salary in half, training two employees for a job that can be satisfied by one employee could increase administrative costs. Employers may also experience a more difficult time finding prospective employees who genuinely want to participate in job share.<ref name="boston_ap" />

{{POV check|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Jon Barela | image = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Las Cruces, New Mexico]] | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = Gina Barela | children = John Paul, Christiana, Joseph | residence = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | relations = | alma_mater = [[Georgetown University]] School of Public Service, [[Georgetown University]] Law School (1987) | occupation = | religion = | signature = | website = [http://jonbarela.com/default.aspx Jon Barela, Congress] | footnotes = }} '''Jon Barela''' is an American business executive. He is the Chief Executive Officer of The Borderplex Alliance, a nonprofit group dedicated to promoting business and economic development in the Ciudad Juárez, El Paso and southern New Mexico region.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/albuquerque/news/2016/08/29/nms-economic-development-secretary-stepping-down.html|title=http://www.bizjournals.com/albuquerque/news/2016/08/29/nms-economic-development-secretary-stepping-down.html|website=www.bizjournals.com|access-date=2016-12-15}}</ref> Previously, he served as Economic Development Secretary for the state of New Mexico<ref name=":0" /> and was the 2010 [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for {{ushr|NM|1}}.<ref name="NM House Candidates">{{cite web | url = http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/external/pre-election/state_districts/NM.html | title = New Mexico Congressional Candidates, Per District | publisher = Associated Press|date=June 24, 2010|accessdate=2010-10-09}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Jon Barela was born and raised in [[Las Cruces, New Mexico]], and attended Las Cruces High School. He earned a bachelor's degree in History and Diplomacy from the [[Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service]] at [[Georgetown University]] in Washington, D.C., receiving a Bachelor of Science in Foreign Service (B.S.) in 1984.<ref name="Georgetown">[http://sfs.georgetown.edu/ Georgetown]</ref> After graduation from [[Georgetown University]] School of Foreign Service,<ref name="Georgetown"/> Barela joined the staff of New Mexico Congressman [[Joe Skeen]]. As a senior aide to the Congressman, he focused on the House appropriations and legislative process. While working for Congressman Skeen, Barela earned his law degree from [[Georgetown University|Georgetown]] in 1987.<ref name="Jon Barela bio">{{cite web|url=http://jonbarela.com/Bio.aspx|title=About Jon|publisher=Jon Barela campaign website|year=2009|accessdate=2010-10-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101008021136/http://jonbarela.com/Bio.aspx|archivedate=2010-10-08|df=}}</ref>
== Career == Barela returned to New Mexico in 1987 and joined the Modrall law firm in Albuquerque. Four years later, he became New Mexico's Assistant Attorney General and Director of the Civil Division under then Attorney General [[Hal Stratton]].
In 1993, Barela joined [[Intel Corporation|Intel]] as its community and government relations manager. He set company benchmarks for outreach into underrepresented communities and was awarded the Intel Achievement Award, the company's highest and most selective honor.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} Barela left Intel in 2005.
;Cerelink After spending most of his career as an attorney and as a state and federal lobbyist, in 2002 Barela decided to become a business owner and entrepreneur.<ref>New Mexico Economic Development Web Site http://www.gonm.biz/About_NMEDD.aspx</ref> He co-founded Cerelink, a technology start-up firm that specialized in complex computer rendering for visual effects in Hollywood films.<ref>"Luring Hollywood to Cloud Computing," Michael White, RREDC, Bloomberg News, Cerelink News Release, 2010</ref> Prior to founding Cerelink, Barela had no prior experience in technology development for the entertainment industry.<ref>NMEDD Web Site http://www.gonm.biz/About_NMEDD.aspx</ref>
During his 2010 congressional campaign, Barela frequently cited his work at Cerelink when described himself as a successful entrepreneur. In 2011, he was questioned by media outlets on whether Cerelink was the beneficiary of tax credits from state government.<ref name="Ducks">"Barela Ducks Questions About State Film Rebate Program, New Mexico Independent, October 11, 2010</ref> In October 2010, Barela told KKOB-AM that those reports were "erroneous."<ref name="Ducks"/> He told the Albuquerque Journal that his company "never received any tax credits, period. That is just flatly inaccurate it is just wrong."<ref>"Barela Touts His NM Roots, DC Experience," Michael Coleman, ABQ Journal. October 10, 2010</ref>
In July 2012, the Albuquerque Journal reported that Cerelink had stopped operations and was bankrupt, leaving the New Mexico Computer Application Center with an outstanding bill of $934,000.<ref>"Hollywood Flop," Kevin Robinson-Avila, "Albuquerque Journal," July 13, 2012</ref> Barela maintains that he had no involvement with Cerelink since 2009, when he resigned from the board and reduced his stake in the company to less than 1 percent of shares.
== Community affairs == Barela has made competitiveness and improving education central themes in his chairmanship of several significant organizations, including the Albuquerque Hispano Chamber of Commerce (one of the country's largest Hispanic chambers), New Mexico First (the state's leading nonpartisan public policy group), New Mexico's Work Force Development Board, and the [[Albuquerque Public Schools]] Foundation. He most recently served on the [[Albuquerque Public Schools]] [[Board of Education]], helping oversee operations of one of the country's largest school districts.<ref name="Jon Barela bio" /> The school board passed a policy that replaced a hot lunch with a meal that included a cheese sandwich, milk or juice, and carrot sticks when the children' parents fell behind with their lunch payments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abqjournal.com/upfront/0110322upfront02-01-09.htm |title=Cheese Sandwich Debate Borders on the Ridiculous |publisher=Albuquerque Journal |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2010-10-10}}</ref> Barela supported the policy, "We don't want to be bailing people out of their responsibility because they know the community is going to step up and pay this bill."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abqjournal.com/news/metro/2411406metro01-24-09.htm |title=APS Seeks Sandwich Alternative |publisher=Albuquerque Journal |date=2010-01-24 |accessdate=2010-10-10}}</ref>
== 2010 U.S. Congressional campaign == {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in New Mexico, 2010#District 1}} Barela challenged Democratic incumbent [[Martin Heinrich]] for {{ushr|NM|1}}, but was ultimately defeated in a 51%-49% race on election night. After the election, he was appointed by Governor [[Susana Martinez]] to serve as secretary of New Mexico's Economic Development Department.
Barela ran unopposed in the primary for [[New Mexico's 1st congressional district]] Republican nomination.<ref name="NM House Candidates" />
=== Political positions === Barela has signed the [[Americans for Tax Reform]] "Taxpayer Protection Pledge", a written promise by legislators and candidates for office that commits them to oppose tax increases.<ref name="Jon Barela Issues">{{cite web |url=http://jonbarela.com/ISSUES.aspx |title=Issues |publisher=Jon Barela campaign website |year=2010 |accessdate=2010-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101008021234/http://jonbarela.com/ISSUES.aspx |archivedate=2010-10-08 |df= }}</ref> He supports programs to encourage parents' involvement in their children's education, and successful programs which show parents and children the connection between education and future success, such as the [[Young Enterprise#Learn To Earn|"Learn and Earn"]] program.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} He cites his experience in the community working on behalf of educational programs as indication that he knows what works and what does not. In regard to the [[Affordable Health Care for America Act]], Barela prefers removing legislative and regulatory barriers to providing insurance, such as allowing interstate pooling for insurance purchase, rather than further government intervention in the health care system.<ref name="Jon Barela Issues" />
Barela has received the highest rating from the [[National Rifle Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nrapvf.org/upcoming-elections/New-Mexico.aspx |title=National Rifle Association Political Victory Fund: New Mexico |accessdate=2010-10-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009093508/http://www.nrapvf.org/upcoming-elections/New-Mexico.aspx |archivedate=2010-10-09 |df= }}</ref> The [[Gun Owners of America]] also gave him their highest rating and their endorsement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gunowners.org/111hrat.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031142902/http://gunowners.org/111hrat.htm |archivedate=2010-10-31 |df= }}</ref>

[[Paolo Barilla]] (brother) | website = }} '''Luca Barilla''' (born 1959) is an Italian [[billionaire]] businessman, and the chairman of [[Barilla Group]], the world's largest pasta company, which is 85% owned by Luca, his brothers Guido and Paolo, and a sister.{{cite web|title=The World's Billionaires: Luca Barilla|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/luca-barilla/|website=Forbes|accessdate=23 January 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barilla, Luca}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Barilla family]] [[Category:Italian billionaires]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Milan]] [[Category:People from Parma]]

{{Infobox company | name = Merrimack Pharmaceuticals | logo = | type = | industry = Pharmaceuticals | fate = | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = 2000 in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = | products = | num_employees = 426 | num_employees_year = 2016 | parent = | website = {{URL|http://www.merrimack.com}} }} '''Merrimack Pharmaceuticals''' is a pharmaceutical company based in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], [[United States]]. They specialize in developing drugs for the treatment of [[cancer]].
Merrimack's first FDA-approved drug was approved in 2015; [[Onivyde]], a liposome encapsulated version of irinotecan is used for treating pancreatic adenocarcinoma. It was approved for use in Europe the following year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investors.merrimackpharma.com/index.cfm|title=Investors - Merrimack|publisher=}}</ref>
== History == Merrimack was founded by a group of scientists from [[MIT]] and [[Harvard University]] in 2000.<ref name="merrimackpharma.com">{{cite web|url=http://investors.merrimackpharma.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1193125-16-480919&CIK=1274792|title=Merrimack - Annual Report|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2016, Merrimack had 426 full-time employees, 103 of which had an MD or PhD.<ref name="merrimackpharma.com"/>
In October 2016, CEO Robert Mulroy resigned and the company announced they would be laying off 20% of its employees.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/merrimack-pharmaceuticals-cuts-jobs-ceo-resigns-amid-restructuring-effort-1475498534|title=Merrimack Pharmaceuticals Cuts Jobs; CEO Resigns Amid Restructuring Effort|first=Joshua|last=Jamerson|date=3 October 2016|publisher=|via=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> In January 2017, interim CEO Gary Crocker resigned and the board of directors appointed Richard Peters to be president and CEO. Peters previously worked at [[Sanofi]] and was a faculty member at Harvard University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investors.merrimackpharma.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1193125-17-14208&CIK=1274792|title=Merrimack - Current Report|publisher=}}</ref>
In January 2017, French pharmaceutical company [[Ipsen]] announced they would be purchasing Onivyde from Merrimack for approximately $1 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/merrimack-pharma-ma-ipsen-idUSL4N1EZ113|title=Ipsen to buy some Merrimack assets for about $1 billion|date=9 January 2017|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref>
== Pipeline == Merrimack has four drugs in clinical development. * [[MM-302]] – [[HER2]] targeting [[antibody-drug conjugate]] * MM-121 ([[seribantumab]]) – anti-[[HER3]] monoclonal antibody * MM-141 ([[istiratumab]]) – [[IGF-1R]] and [[HER3]] bispecific monoclonal antibody * [[MM-151]] – anti-[[Epidermal growth factor receptor|EGFR]] mixture of monoclonal antibody

{{New Netherland}} [[File:Michiel Pauw (1590- ).jpg|thumb|Michiel Pauw, 1618]] [[File:Jan van der Heyden - Canal in Amsterdam.jpg|thumb|260px|The greyish mansion in the middle, belonging to Pauw, was painted by [[Jan van der Heyden]]]]
'''Knight Michiel Reiniersz Pauw''' (29 March 1590 in [[Amsterdam]]<ref>Baptized 8 April 1590 in the [[Nieuwe Kerk (Amsterdam)|Nieuwe Kerk]], Mijchgiel, son of Reijier Pau and Cornelisgen Mijchgiels {{cite web |url=http://stadsarchief.amsterdam.nl/archieven/archiefbank/indexen/doopregisters/zoek/index.nl.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722201159/https://stadsarchief.amsterdam.nl/archieven/archiefbank/indexen/doopregisters/zoek/index.nl.html |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }}</ref> – 20 March 1640 in [[Ghent]]) was a [[burgomaster|burgemeester]] of [[Amsterdam]] and a director of the [[Dutch West India Company]] (WIC).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicbookshelf.com/public_html/Our_Country_Vol_1/newnether_eg.html|title=New Netherland Colony|website=www.publicbookshelf.com|accessdate=24 June 2017}}</ref>
[[Image:H170bo.jpg|thumb|right|260px|A contemporary image of the same row of houses]]
He was born in [[Amsterdam]] in a rich merchant family - his father, Reinier Pauw (1564–1636) wasn't only a merchant, but also a [[Mayor of Amsterdam]] - and studied law in [[Leiden]]. His brother [[Adriaan Pauw]] <ref>http://www.herenvanholland.nl/eigenaar.cfm?eigenaarnummer=472{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> (1581 - February 21, 1653 [https://web.archive.org/web/20060208112405/http://home.zonnet.nl/d.van.duijvenbode/geschmin.htm]) was [[Grand Pensionary]] of [[Holland]] from 1631 to 1636 and from 1651 to 1653, and signatory of the [[Peace of Münster]] (1648) for which he was instrumental as ambassador for Holland.
The WIC was founded in 1621 to exploit trade in the [[Western Hemisphere]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/westind.htm|title=The Avalon Project : Charter of the Dutch West India Company : 1621|publisher=|accessdate=24 June 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014040932/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/westind.htm|archivedate=14 October 2008|df=}}</ref> and by 1625 had established a colony at [[Fort Amsterdam]] ([[Lower Manhattan]]) and [[Fort Orange]]. In the hope of encouraging settlement the company, in 1629, started to offer vast land grants and the feudal title of [[patroon]].<ref name=autogenerated1>Johan van Hartskamp, De Westindische Compangnie en haar Belangen in Niuew-Nederland, een overzicht (1621-1664)http://stuyvesant.library.uu.nl {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206205901/http://stuyvesant.library.uu.nl/ |date=2008-02-06 }}</ref> under the auspices of the [[Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions]]. In 1630, Pauw purchased two tracts from the [[Lenape]] at Hopoghan Hackingh ([[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]]) and at Ashasimus ([[Harsimus]]), covering the entire peninsula between the [[Hudson River]] and [[Hackensack River]] now known as [[Hudson County, New Jersey]], as well as a third purchase of Staten Eylandt ([[Staten Island]]), now part of [[New York City]].<ref>https://archive.org/details/historyofcountyo01winfWinfiled, CHarles (1874) History of the county of Hudson, New Jersey : from its earliest settlement to the present time pp.13-25</ref> The [[patroon]]ship was given the [[Latin]]ized form of his surname (which means "peacock"), [[Pavonia, New Netherland|Pavonia]]. It is said it was sold to him by the Manhattans after they had retreated there after the sale of their home island to [[Peter Minuit]] some years before. Initially, a small hut and ferry landing were built at Arresick, called Powles Hoek ([[Paulus Hook]]), but Pauw failed to fulfill the other conditions set forth by the company (which included populating the area with at least fifty adults),<ref name=autogenerated1 /> and was later required to sell his interests back to it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kellscraft.com/DutchEnglishOnHudson/DutchEnglishOnHudsonCh03.html|title=The Dutch and English on the Hudson: Chapter 3|website=www.kellscraft.com|accessdate=24 June 2017}}</ref> In 1634 he collaborated with [[Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)|Kiliaen van Rensselaer]] and [[Wouter van Twiller]] in sending cattle (horses and cows) in the next six years.<ref>NA 373, f. 129-130, Not. W. Cluijt, 13 April 1634</ref>
The name Pavonia remains as an avenue and library branch in contemporary Jersey City. There is also a Pavonia Court in Bayonne and Pavonia Avenue in Kearny. [[Erie Railroad]]'s Hudson waterfront terminus was called [[Pavonia Terminal]] located nearby [[Port Authority Trans-Hudson|PATH]] rapid transit system's station once called [[Newport (PATH station)|Pavonia]]. [[Saint Peter's College (New Jersey)|Saint Peter's College]], located on land that was part of the patroonship, has as its mascot a peacock.
Pavonia was not the only American territory that would bear his name. First described by [[Amerigo Vespucci (explorer)|Amerigo Vespucci]], who traveled with a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] expedition of [[Gonçalo Coelho]] to [[Brazil]] in the year 1503, the [[Fernando de Noronha]] Archipelago was invaded by the [[England|English]], and from 1556 until 1612, was held by the [[France|French]]. In 1628, it was occupied by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]], who were displaced two years later by a [[Spain|Spanish]]-Portuguese military expedition led by [[Rui Calaza Borges]]. The Dutch occupied the island once again in 1635, making it a hospital for their troops who occupied Northeastern Brazil (the Brazilian coast between Rio São Francisco and Maranhão). The island became known as ''[[Fernando de Noronha|Pavonia]]'', in honor of Pauw. It would remain under Dutch control for nearly twenty years, when it was reconquered by Portugal.
Pauw was apparently very successful, and was able to commission one of the most popular architects of the period to build a ''grachtenpand'', or canal house, in Amsterdam. It may be seen in the two lead images for this article. Clad in white sandstone imported from Germany it, was the first in the city to have a ''neck'' [[gable]]. <ref>http://www.theaterinstituut.nl/en/theatermuseum/theatermuseum/de_panden{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{ infobox Politician | name = Muriel Pénicaud | image = Portrait Muriel Pénicaud (cropped).jpg | office = [[Minister of Social Affairs (France)|French Minister of Labour]] | term_start = 17 May 2017 | term_end = | president = [[Emmanuel Macron]] | primeminister = [[Édouard Philippe]] | predecessor = [[Myriam El Khomri]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1955|03|31}} | birth_place = [[Versailles, Yvelines|Versailles]], France | nationality = French | party = [[La République En Marche!]] | children = 2 | alma_mater = [[Paris Nanterre University]]
[[University of Strasbourg]]
[[INSEAD]] }} '''Muriel Pénicaud''' (born 31 March 1955) is a French public official. She was the executive vice president of [[human resources]] at [[Dassault Systèmes]] from 2002 to 2008, and at [[Groupe Danone]] from 2008 to 2014. She was appointed as the French [[Minister of Social Affairs (France)|Minister of Labour]] on 17 May 2017.{{cite news|title=Muriel Pénicaud, une ministre du Travail au "profil exemplaire" selon les patrons|url=http://lentreprise.lexpress.fr/rh-management/droit-travail/muriel-penicaud-ministre-du-travail_1909003.html|accessdate=17 May 2017|work=L'Express|date=17 May 2017}} ==Early life== Muriel Pénicaud was born in March 1955.{{cite web|title=Executive Management|url=http://en.businessfrance.fr/governance|website=Business France|accessdate=17 May 2017}} She graduated from [[Paris Nanterre University]]. ==Career== Pénicaud worked for the French [[Minister of Social Affairs (France)|Minister of Labour]] from 1985 to 2002. She was an advisor to Minister [[Jean-Louis Bianco]] from 1991 to 1992, and to Minister [[René Teulade]] from 1992 to 1993. Pénicaud worked for [[Groupe Danone]] from 1993 to 2002. She was the Executive Vice-President of Organization, Human Resources and Sustainable Development for [[Dassault Systèmes]] from 2002 to 2008. She returned to the Groupe Danone in 2008, where she was Executive Vice-President, Human Resources until 2014. She receives between 2012 and 2014 more than 4,7 million euros of remuneration for this activity. In addition, in April 2013, she realizes a capital gain of 1,1 million euros by dismissing 900 employees.http://www.liberation.fr/france/2017/07/27/la-juteuse-plus-value-boursiere-de-muriel-penicaud-chez-danone_1586672 Pénicaud was appointed as the French Ambassador for International Investment in May 2014, and as the CEO of [[Business France]] on 1 January 2015. In this capacity, she promoted foreign investment in France to boost job creation.{{cite news|first=Coralie|last=Cathelinais|title=Muriel Pénicaud, l'ancienne DRH de Danone, devient ministre du Travail|url=http://bfmbusiness.bfmtv.com/france/muriel-penicaud-une-ex-cadre-de-danone-orange-et-dassault-devient-ministre-du-travail-1165824.html|accessdate=17 May 2017|work=BFM Business|date=17 May 2017}} Pénicaud became a knight of the [[Legion of Honour]] in 2009.{{cite web|title=Muriel Pénicaud: Biographie|url=https://www.franceinter.fr/personnes/muriel-penicaud|website=France Inter|accessdate=17 May 2017}} She serves on the board of directors of [[SNCF]] and [[Paris-Saclay]].{{cite web|title=OUR BOARD OF DIRECTORS|url=http://www.sncf.com/en/group/board-of-directors|website=SNCF|accessdate=17 May 2017}}{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://www.epaps.fr/en/governance/board-of-directors/|website=Paris-Saclay|accessdate=17 May 2017}} Pénicaud was appointed as the French Minister of Labour on 17 May 2017. ==Controversies== A formal investigation has been opened in July 2017 into "possible favouritism" in the organisation of a Las Vegas technology event by Business France under the tenure of Penicaud. The French daily ''Libération'' recently underlined that she was suspected of having provided a "truncated overview of the audit" to Business France's board of directors. As a human resources director at Danone in the 1990s, Muriel Pénicaud made $1.4 million from stock options while cutting 900 jobs, according to Bloomberg. ==Personal life== Pénicaud has two children. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Penicaud, Muriel}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]] [[Category:INSEAD alumni]] [[Category:Human resource management people]] [[Category:Groupe Danone people]] [[Category:French corporate directors]] [[Category:French Ministers for Work and Social Security]] [[Category:Women government ministers of France]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:21st-century French politicians]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:People from Versailles]]

{{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{Infobox film | name = Muro-Ami (Reef Hunters) | image = muro-ami.jpg | caption = GMA Films' Muro Ami (Reef Hunters) | director = [[Marilou Diaz-Abaya]] | story = [[Marilou Diaz-Abaya]] | starring =[[Cesar Montano]] as Fredo
[[Pen Medina]] as Dado
[[Amy Austria]] as Susan
[[Jhong Hilario]] as Botong
[[Rebecca Lusterio]] as Kalbo/Amy | screenplay =[[Ricardo Lee]] and [[Jun Lana]] | cinematography =[[Rody Lacap]] | editing =[[Jesus Navarro]] | distributor = [[GMA Films]] | released = {{Film date|1999|12|25|df=y}} | country = Philippines | runtime = 114 minutes | language = [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] }} '''''Muro-Ami''''' (''Reef Hunters'') is a 1999 [[Cinema of the Philippines|Filipino film]] that depicts one of the worst forms of [[child labor]] in the illegal fishing system. The film follows the story of Fredo, a ruthless captain of 150 [[muro-ami]] divers, who employ illegal fishing practices, such as pounding and crushing corals to scare fish, driving them towards the nets. With a high quota to meet, Fredo forces the divers, who consist mostly of children, to accomplish at least eight dives a day to meet their goal before the millennium. Tired and harassed after the burdensome task being given to them, the children have to make do in subhuman conditions in the Muro Ami boat, ''The Aurora''. They sleep in rat-infested bunks and are fed only twice a day. Life above the water in the boat is much worse than the suffering the children encounter beneath the sea. For every dive, a child's life is perilously in danger. On January 22, 2008, [[filmmaker]] Nick Deocampo, [[Executive director|Director]] of the [[Movie Workers Welfare Foundation]] (Mowelfund) announced the holding of a Ricardo Lee Film Festival from February 4 to 10, 2008 – the World Arts Festival under Mayor Tito Sarion, in [[Daet]] city, [[Camarines Norte]]. Lee's scripts became Philippine [[Film|cinema]] [[classics]] of Philippine cinema, which made the 2nd golden age of 1980 Filipino [[movies]]. 5 [[films]] will be shown in the festival: [[Gina Alajar]]'s "[[Salome]]," "[[Anak]]," "Muro Ami," "Gumapang Ka sa Lusak", and "Memories of Old Manila".[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=106550 Abs-Cbn Interactive, Ricky Lee to be honored in Daet arts festival] == Plot == Fredo ([[Cesar Montano]]) is a fisherman who has endured more than his share of hardship in life; his wife and child both perished in a boating accident, and today Fredo approaches each trip to the sea with the angry determination of a man out for revenge. Fredo commands a crew of young people from poor families as he takes his rattletrap ship into the ocean in search of fish that live along the reefs, snaring catch with an illegal netting system. Not all of Fredo's youthful sailors are willing to put up with his abusive arrogance, however, and even his father Dado ([[Pen Medina]]) and close friend Botong ([[Jhong Hilario]]) have grown weary of Fredo's tirades. Fredo's body is beginning to betray him as well, and as he and his crew damage the sea's reef beds in search of fish, no one is certain how much longer he will be able to continue. Maestro Fredo, a tyrant captain, fixates to claim the treasures of the sea—no matter what, in whatever diabolical technique for as long as he profits. He employs dozens of men, mostly children, in his dangerous expeditions. Conditions aboard the ships are oppressive. Children are often overworked and his crew is furious with the way they are living. He blames the sea for claiming the lives of his family and he exacts revenge by plundering its depths. == Cast == * [[Cesar Montano]] – Fredo Obsioma * [[Pen Medina]] – Diyos-Dado Lacar * [[Amy Austria]] – Susan Bacor * [[Jhong Hilario]] – Botong Maldepena * [[Rebecca Lusterio]] – Kalbo Kee * [[Jerome Sales]] – Filemon Dolotallas * [[Teodoro Penaranda Jr.]] – Tibor Lague * [[Ariel Estoquia Mijos]] – Bahoy Ballasabas == Production == Direction: [[Marilou Diaz-Abaya]]

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Nemko.gif|right]] --> '''Norges Elektriske Materiellkontroll''' ('''NEMKO''') is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] private organization that supervises safety testing for electrical equipment manufacturing.
The Nemko Group offers testing, inspection and [[product certification|certification]] services concerning products, machinery, installations and systems worldwide.
==History==
The original NEMKO was established in 1933 as an institution for mandatory safety testing and national approval of electrical equipment marketed and sold in [[Norway]] for connection to the [[public utility]] network.
Later, testing of [[Electromagnetic interference|radio interference]] requirements became another part of the approval regime.
In 1990, as Norway entered into the [[European Economic Area]] agreement, [[European Union directive|European Community Directives]] for product safety were adopted, and the traditional mandatory approval scheme was abandoned. As this stage, NEMKO was transformed into an independent, self-owned foundation, having a council of representatives from different interest groups ([[industry]] and [[trade]] organizations, [[consumer]] associations, utility companies etc.) as the highest level of supervision. At the same time, the foundation established and became the sole owner of Nemko AS, which constitutes the central operating company and is responsible for what is today denoted the Nemko Group.
Since 1992, both the scope of [[Service (economics)|service]]s and the global presence of Nemko have been greatly expanded.

{{Infobox publisher | name = ODS-Petrodata | image = | parent = [[IHS Inc.]] | status = Acquired By [[IHS Inc.]] | founded = 2002 | keypeople = [[Per Christian Grytnes]]
([[President]] and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]){{cite web|url=http://www.ods-petrodata.com/odsp/about.php|title=IHS Home Page|publisher=ods-petrodata.com|accessdate=2016-07-25}} | country = UK, United States, Norway | headquarters = [[Oslo]], [[Aberdeen]], [[Houston]] | numemployees = 100-200 | url = [http://www.ods-petrodata.com www.ods-petrodata.com] }} '''ODS-Petrodata''' is a [[market intelligence]] company specialised in the upstream offshore oil and gas industry. ODS-Petrodata is considered an authoritative source for market intelligence, data, market research and consulting services. "ODS-Petrodata has been a leading provider of market intelligence and data to the offshore oil and gas industry [by association with its previous entities, ] since 1974"http://www.eng.nus.edu.sg/core/talks/EveningLecture-16092008.pdf{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Deepwater+Rig+Market+to+Stay+in+the+Doldrums,+According+to...-a0109168838|title=Deepwater Rig Market to Stay in the Doldrums, According to ODS-Petrodata Report. - Free Online Library|publisher=thefreelibrary.com|accessdate=2016-07-25}} ==History== ODS-Petrodata was founded in 2002 from the merger of Offshore Data Services Inc., Petrodata Ltd. and Bassoe Offshore Consultants Ltd., each a provider of "data, information and market intelligence to the offshore energy industry". ODS-Petrodata's website claims that their organisation has existed in some form since 1973.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110418005740/en/IHS-Acquires-ODS-Petrodata|title=IHS Acquires ODS-Petrodata | Business Wire|publisher=businesswire.com|accessdate=2016-07-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.subsea.org/company/listdetails.asp?companyid=2294|title=ODS-Petrodata - Subsea Oil and Gas Directory Information|publisher=subsea.org|accessdate=2016-07-25}} In the recent years, they also starting producing tools and publications oriented towards the offshore renewables market.{{cite web|url=http://www.aberdeenrenewables.com/members/complete-a-z-index/ods-petrodata/|title=Ods-Petrodata – Aberdeen Renewable Energy Group|publisher=aberdeenrenewables.com|accessdate=2016-07-25}} ==Locations== ODS-Petrodata operates from offices in Houston, Aberdeen, Oslo, Singapore and Dubai. ==Acquisition== ODS-Petrodata was acquired by [[IHS Inc.]] in April 2011.{{cite web|url=http://press.ihs.com/press-release/corporate-financial/ihs-acquires-ods-petrodata|title=IHS Acquires ODS-Petrodata | IHS Online Newsroom|publisher=press.ihs.com|accessdate=2016-07-25}}http://www.companiesandmarkets.com/news/specialist-offshore-information-provider-ods-petrodata-acquired-by-ihs-inc-n718.aspx?prk=33f895519277bace25c442b39bd0a1e3 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.ods-petrodata.com}} [[Category:Business intelligence companies]] [[Category:2011 mergers and acquisitions]]

[[Gussie Busch|August Anheuser "Gussie" Busch Jr.]] (maternal grandfather) | website = }} '''Robert Ringen Hermann Jr.''' (born 1953/1954) is a St. Louis businessman, president, CEO, and chairman of Hermann Companies Inc., founded by his father, and one of St. Louis' largest private sector employers. ==Early life== He is the son of [[Bob Hermann|Robert Ringen Hermann Sr.]] (born 1923) and Lilly Busch (1923–1995), and grandson of [[Gussie Busch|August Anheuser "Gussie" Busch Jr]].{{cite news|title=Signa Vernon Merrill Plans to Marry Robert Ringen Hermann Jr. in June|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/27/style/signa-vernon-merrill-plans-to-marry-robert-ringen-hermann-jr-in-june.html|accessdate=October 8, 2015|work=nytimes|date=May 27, 1990}} He was educated at [[Deerfield Academy]] and [[Princeton University]]. ==Career== Hermann is the president, CEO, and chairman of Hermann Companies Inc. (one of St. Louis' largest private sector employers) and Anchor Packaging, a partner and advisor at Pfingsten Partners LLC, a director of Priority Transportation LLC, and of the First National Bank of St. Louis.{{cite web|title=Executive Profile Robert Ringen Hermann Jr.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=589221&privcapId=4301705|website=bloomberg|accessdate=October 8, 2015}}{{cite news|title=The family tree: Not all Busches|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/stories/2008/06/23/story4.html|accessdate=October 8, 2015|work=bizjournals|date=June 22, 2008}} ==Personal life== In 1990, he married Signa Vernon Merrill, the daughter of Mr and Mrs Robert Gordon Merrill of Locust Valley, Long Island, New York. It was his second marriage, the first having ended in divorce. In December 2014, their daughter, Merrill Clark Hermann, was crowned Queen of Love and Beauty at the 130th annual [[Veiled Prophet Ball]].{{cite news|title=Merrill Clark Hermann is picked at Veiled Prophet Ball|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/merrill-clark-hermann-is-picked-at-veiled-prophet-ball/article_cedb423b-de63-53b5-9b9e-e4f5bb016163.html|accessdate=October 9, 2015|work=stltoday|date=December 20, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hermann, Robert Ringen}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1950s births]] [[Category:Deerfield Academy alumni]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Businesspeople from St. Louis]] [[Category:Busch family]]
